Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: BRAIDING: Braiding Majorana bound states in atomic chains on a superconducting island
Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-technical Abstract:
Majorana bound states are localized at the edge of a one-dimensional topological superconductor. These excitations are viewed as a starting point for topological quantum information processing. This award supports experimental research activity aiming to address the key challenges related to establishing control of Majorana bound states. This particular implementation avoids technical challenges related to physically moving Majorana bound states and, due to the small size of the superconducting island, has intrinsic protection against errors. If successful, this research activity has a potential to make transformative breakthrough in the field of quantum science and technology. The research aspect of this project is accompanied by a multifaceted educational program for graduate and undergraduate students as well as outreach program targeting high-school students and science teachers from the Pasadena School District. The research advances of the project will be broadly disseminated through research articles, seminars, courses and public lectures.

Technical Abstract:
This award supports experimental efforts aiming towards a demonstration of a topological quantum bit based on Majorana bound states realized in magnetic atomic chains placed on a superconducting island which is integrated into a mesoscopic interferometer circuit. In this scheme, reading out the quantum information encoded in Majorana states and performing quantum logical operations can be done by measuring electron parity using interferometry. This particular implementation combines the advantages of theoretical proposals which avoid technical challenges related to physically moving Majorana bound states with intrinsic protection against the quasi-particle poisoning which is considered to be major limiting factor for the coherence times of topological quantum systems. In order to realize this experimental platform several approaches for integration of atomic assemblies accessible using scanning probe microscopy into a nano-fabricated mesoscopic interferometer device will be explored. If successful, this highly focused research activity has a potential to make transformative breakthrough in the fields of quantum science and technology. The research aspect of this project is accompanied by a multifaceted educational program for graduate and undergraduate students as well as outreach program targeting high-school students and science teachers from the Pasadena School District. The research advances of the project will be broadly disseminated through research articles, seminars, courses and public lectures.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award sponsored the development of experimental techniques needed for establishing control of topological modes in atomic size circuits investigated using Scanning Tunneling Microscopy (STM). The proposed method for the realization of these modes relies on the STM imaging of two-dimensional materials and placing atomic structures on top of them. Within the duration of the project, we have developed a set of experimental methods for the fabrication of ultra-clean gated graphene heterostructures suitable for atomic resolution imaging. This critical development is the first step for the realization of the proposed scheme for controlling topological modes. Using the developed techniques we also showed imaging of other two-dimensional systems such as graphene-niobium selenide heterostructures and the newly discovered magic-angle twisted bilayer graphene. Future research efforts will focus on the assembly of atomic structures on these systems in search of topological modes.

The Pi, postdoctoral researcher and graduate student working on the project presented the main results in several international conferences including the American Physical Society and Material Research Society meetings. We published the main findings in the Nature Physics journal. Also, this project provided an opportunity for several undergraduate students to join our lab and work over summer. The PI also gave numerous lectures for the general audience, high-school and undergraduate students. One of these lectures, held in November this year, belongs to the famous Caltech's Watson lecture series. This lecture is available online on Caltech's YouTube channel: (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aUcCE9ILH4s).
